subject: RE: [junit] JUnit in Action
msgSnippet: Another book I like is the JUnit Pocket Guide. It s small and cheap, but it provides the details about JUnit as well as an overview of developer testing.
messageBody:
Another book I like is the JUnit Pocket Guide. It's small and cheap, but it
provides the details about JUnit as well as an overview of developer
testing. Conflict of interest warning--I wrote it.

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Chip Dunning
> Sent: Wednesday, September 28, 2005 7:38 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit in Action
>
> The 3 JUnit books on my shelves - all of which I find very useful.
>
> Unit Testing in Java
> JUnit in Action
> JUnit Recipes
>
> I also have Pragmatic Unit Testing, but I just do not refer
> to that one as
> much. I cannot explain why I do not reach for it, but it
> usually involves
> that JUnit Recipes solves all my reference problems - so I reach there
> first.
>
> Out of all of those I would have to say that Unit Testing in
> Java was my
> favorite because it was that book that first made things
> click for me. It is
> well thumbed and annotated like my "Thinking in Java", "Code
> Complete", and
> "Programming Windows 95" books.
>
>
> Chip
> --
> "The reason the mainstream is considered a stream is because it's so
> shallow" --George Carlin
>
>
> On 9/27/05, guilherme mello <guilhermemello18@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hi..
> >
> > I am thinking about buying this book.. and what they advise to me?
> >
> > This book is a good book to study unit tests ?
> >
> >
> >
>
